11:12 am
BE11:12am

The path to a no-deal scenario is now tangible. The Conservatives are likely to replace Theresa May with a 'no-deal candidate', probably Boris Johnson and probably before summer recess on 20 July, who is willing to embrace the legal, default position of “no-deal” should there be no agreement in place by 31 October. The indicative votes on 27 March showed that there is a clear majority of MPs opposing leaving the EU without a deal (400 vs 160). While MPs can hope that any new Prime Minister adheres to the democratic will of the House of Commons, it is unclear whether MPs have the legal power to stop the PM from pursuing no-deal and pass a corresponding law - else the default position is to leave without a deal on 31 October. The legally open route is to bring a vote of no-confidence and early General Elections, opening the path for Jeremy Corbyn to become the new Prime Minister. Both scenarios are likely to impact UK assets negatively which the market has started to price in and is likely to continue to price in over the next few weeks as some of the above scenarios are crystalizing.

Bluesky21 The leadership debate will be like "Trump and the seven dwarfs" as Trump would like to call it
BE11:12am

So what to do?

Bluesky21 Whoever started already with the highest media profile wins
BE11:13am

FTSE100 USD vs SPX Put Switch
In our Outlook for 2019 we recommended a put switch on FTSE100-USD vs SPX to protect against a disorderly Brexit scenario, which merits revisiting now

11:13 am
BE11:13am

And buy FTSE-USD 6M 95% Put at 2.9% vs SPX 6M 95% Puts at 2.65%, indicatively.

BE11:14am

We use the FTSE-USD not the FTSE: 70% of FTSE 100 earnings are earned abroad, leading to a negative correlation between GBP/USD and FTSE 100 levels (currently, -10% at a 70 day window using 1 day returns). We use the FTSE-USD (UKXUSD Index) in order to play the contemporaneous hit on currency and equities that would materialize in a hard Brexit scenario. Over the two-week period following the initial Brexit referendum in June 2016, the FTSE-USD underperformed the FTSE by around 13%.

BE11:15am

Since the referendum in June 2016 the sector has traded as one of the best proxies for Brexit risk in the equity space. In the
2 days following the referendum in June 2016 the sector was down ~40%.
Since the beginning of the year the sector rallied 25% and has since retraced ~10%. The 3 best performing constituents YTD
- Taylor Wimpey, Bovis Homes, Barratt Development – were up 36% on average at the peak on 24 Apr and are still up
21% YTD while some names have started to give up virtually all gains YTD ( Persimmon +2.1%, Countryside Property
+0.8%, Berkeley Group +0.9%).
Investors who want to gain leveraged downside exposure to the sector can do so via a Put on the equally weighted basket
of the 3 aforementioned names (TW/ LN, BVS LN, BDEV LN) – the 2m 95% Put at 2.9%, indicatively.
The maturity lines up with the expected results of the leadership contest in the Conservative party. The Premium can be
cheapened by 35% to 2.15% if one trades the best-of-put instead.
The equivalent 6m 90% Put, covering the planned exit date –and the potential disorderly exit – costs indicatively
4.85% (equally weighted) and 3.6% (best-of-put).

BE11:22am

Here's Canaccord.

BE11:22am

We would sell PFG at the current level for 3 reasons: 1) at the current price for NSF of 48.55p, the price implied by the offer terms for PFG is 431p, which implies 8.8% downside from yesterday’s closing price of 472.6p; 2) our fair value estimate for PFG as a standalone entity is 426p, which implies 9.9% downside from yesterday’s close (we upgraded to Hold post the announcement of the bid), 3) as a stand-alone business we have concerns about the dividend and capital position. Post IFRS16 impact, exceptionals for redundancies and exceptionals related to NSF offer, our estimate of surplus capital falls to £36m in FY19 and £10m in FY20, versus management's minimum buffer of £50m. The result will have to be putting the brakes on growth, which doesn’t seem to be the case judging by record new business in Moneybarn reported in the recent Q1 update, a dividend cut or suspension, and/or a capital raise if the home credit turnaround takes longer than we expect or Vanquis/ Moneybarn impairments are higher than we expect. The next milestone in the process is 5 June, by which time NSF must receive FCA/PRA approval for the combination.

BE11:24am

A reminder that NSF got 53.5% acceptances, including 92% rejections from Provident shareholders, and still declared its offer unconditional.

BE11:34am

Pass the popcorn. It's going to be an interesting few months if Ocado's co-founders spend their time ripping each other apart while the clock ticks down on the online grocer's longtime contract with Waitrose.

Further revelations over the past week have demonstrated just how much business can be governed by personalities. Jonathan Faiman, who set up Ocado with Tim Steiner and Jason Gissing nearly two decades ago, has now set up a rival business to serve Waitrose, 11 years after leaving the business. Non-compete clauses typically only last 12 months, but that hasn't stopped Steiner from exploding with fury about his former friend's "betrayal".

11:35 am

BE11:35am

BE11:35am

As a reminder, TDP was recently created by Jonathan Faiman, one of Ocado’s original founders, to help set up automated CFCs for Waitrose. Hillary was reportedly responsible for helping develop Ocado’s logistics and automation processes as head of development and engineering, as well as designing and building its customer fulfilment centres. Creating a viable competitor to Ocado is certainly a huge task, but this move gives TDP a credibility boost.

BE11:39am

The selloff began yesterday when Neilsen's April-May data showed double-digit declines in US cigarette sales by volume, with BAT the worst of the big four.

BE11:40am

The selloff continued this morning because Altria fell a lot post the UK close, sector rotation type reasons as much as volume data .....

BE11:41am

Now, the thing we always note about Neilsen retail data is that it oversamples urban areas

11:41 am
BE11:42am

...... and the metrosexuals are all now Juuling, whereas it seems country folk smoke while driving their pickups to Target or whatnot.

BE11:42am

So the bad reading doesn't necessarily mean BAT's US volume guidance is impossible.

BE11:43am

Here's Citi's readthrough.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

Earlier today Nielsen reported that industry volumes fell -11.2% in the 4 weeks to May 18. . Afterwards MO shares fell about 4% and BAT fell 3%. Imperial was down only 2.4%, but it had already fallen 12% in the last month, and now trades on a dividend yield of about 10%.

BE11:43am

However, volumes in MSAi were “only” -6.4% in the same period -- This is still a very bad figure, but it is a lot, lot better than the Nielsen one. In the 4 weeks to April 20, MSAi volumes were -6.2% (and Nielsen was -8.5%). MSAi is the industry database, and it is the basis that the industry uses for measuring cigarette volumes. We regard it as much more reliable than Nielsen.

BE11:44am

We believe part of the difference is due to the very tough comp in Nielsen – Nielsen volumes were running about 2-2½ percentage points worse than MSAi in recent periods, but in May Nielsen was almost 5 points worse than MSAi. We suspect the extra-wide gap reflects a very different comp in Nielsen more than anything else. (We believe the ongoing difference is because Nielsen takes its data from larger stores and larger SKUs, and we believe both have been hit harder by Juul than the smaller, more out-of-the-way stores and the smaller SKUs.)

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Looking forward we expect gradually less bad volumes in Nielsen in the rest of the year as the comps get easier – The companies say nothing fundamental has changed. Altria still expects about -4% to -5% industry volumes this year; we think the figure will be about -6%.

11:45 am
BE11:46am

E-cig category growth continues to be driven by JUUL which contributed 101% of unit growth and 92% of dollar growth with an impressive ~74% dollar share. The category's total dollar sales grew 58.8%, although below the 12-week trend of +71.7%. Meanwhile, unit volumes grew 46.4%, compared to the 12-week trend of 54.1% growth. On a sequential basis, the category's dollar sales were up 4.5%, while unit volumes were up 5.7%. By product type, YoY dollar sales growth was due to cartridges (up 81.5%), with kits down 14.6% and disposables down 1.7%.

BE11:47am

JUUL continues to post robust YoY share gains as its dollar share was up 10.3 pts (to 74.5%) and its unit volume share was up 17.9 pts (to 62.6%). JUUL posted YoY dollar growth of 84.3%, which was below the 12-week trend of up 113.5%. Sequentially, JUUL's dollar sales were up ~5%, after declines seen in the first two periods of 2019. BAT's Vuse lost 0.7 pts in dollar share YoY (to 13.2%), and lost 4.0 pts in unit volume share (to 16.1%). Sequentially, BAT's dollar and unit share declined by 0.4 pts and 0.5 pts, respectively. Meanwhile, IMB's blu lost 3.0 pts in dollar share (to 4.3%), while its unit volume share fell 3.7 pts (to 6.3%). JT's Logic saw its dollar share fall 1.6 pts YoY (to 2.3%), while its unit volume share was down 2.4 pts (to 3.8%) in the period. NJOY gained 2.8 pts of dollar share (to 4.4%), while its unit volume share was up 5.7 pts (to 8.9%) in the period.

BE11:48am

It's slightly dangerous, I suggest, to have the US vape market dominated by the one that hoofs most nicotine into its pipes and has at least historically used the sharpest marketing methods to attract new users rather than combustible switchers.

11:48 am

We're in a place where it's take one big regulatory action and the entire category could disappear.

11:53 am
Telford Homes PLC (TEF:LSE): Last: 294.50, down 8.5 (-2.81%), High: 299.00, Low: 281.00, Volume: 108.21k
BE11:54am

Record final results. Full-year revenues increased by 12% to £354m, with PBT of £40.1m in line with expectations (FY18: £46m). The operating margin was 360bps lower at 13.1% due to the increased proportion of lower gross margin Build to Rent (BTR) sites and higher sales costs incurred due to the more challenging sales environment. EPS was 44.5p, with the dividend held at 17p. Balance sheet and dividend. The group ended the year with net debt £10m lower at £93m, with gearing at 37% (FY18; 52%). The continued shift into BTR development and associated cash flow benefits will drive debt levels lower and we forecast gearing to reduce further to c25% over the next 2-3 years. All of Telford’s sites are expected to contribute to profit growth over the next few years, providing support for our forecast NAV of 344p for the year to March 2020. The dividend of 17p is expected to be at least maintained over our forecast period. Current trading and growth outlook. Trading since the group’s last update in February has been in line with expectations. The group is actively engaged in identifying new opportunities to add to the development pipeline, with a particular focus on those that suit BTR and the new partnerships with Invesco Real Estate and M&G Real Estate. The current development pipeline contains c4,900 homes and management now expects c70% of the pipeline to be on BTR developments. The remaining 30% of developments are to be led by individual sale, with an average selling price of c£550k. Forecasts and valuation. We leave our FY20 and FY21 PBT forecasts unchanged and introduce a FY22 PBT forecast of £40m as the group rebuilds profitability. The rebuild of profits over the next few years will be supported by the group’s increased focus on lower risk and less capital-intensive BTR developments, which we forecast to rise to over 50% of profits by FY21. The shares are trading on an undemanding P/NAV of 0.9x for FY20, falling to 0.8x for FY21. The PE multiples are 11.8x and 9.2x, respectively, with an attractive dividend yield of 5.6%. We leave our 350p target price and Buy recommendation unchanged.

BE11:55am

That's Peel Hunt. This is Shore.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Valuation

Given the number of unusual factors bearing on Telford’s earnings in the current and next financial years, establishing fair value is difficult. While we are confident that the strategic re-positioning will have allowed profits to normalise and stabilise by FY2022F, we appreciate that this sits outside many investors’ timeframes. We are confident that Telford can restore profits to at least last year’s level by FY2022F and that the quality of earnings it will then be delivering will be higher than today because of the shift to more BTR.

BTR is, in our view, still firmly a growth market and this, plus the low risk and capital-light structure, generates a higher quality of earnings than sales made in the open market segment. Where house builders undertake a mix of tenures in their development profile, we believe that higher ratings are typically secured. BTR also allows for a stronger balance sheet and should result in more generous dividends for shareholders.

Against this third-year forecast, the shares are trading on 6.9x PE, having recently been closer to just 6x. Given our views on earnings quality here and where we believe ratings elsewhere in the sector are heading as the cycle in mainstream housing turns down, we feel this is too low. This is reinforced by our view that material growth is deliverable beyond the current forecast window (to FY2022F) when other house builders may be struggling for growth.

Shares remain undervalued – trading below NAV

As above we see the group’s prospects and rating to be mis-aligned. Another key point to note on the valuation is that the shares are, uniquely for the quoted house builders, trading below NAV: FY2019A NAV has been reported at 333p per share, some 15% above the current share price even after the recent share price uptick. While we do not tend to value the UK house builders by reference to NAV (we prefer to use earnings), we do recognise that it is very hard for a share price in this sector to be sustained at below book value. Telford is still expected to make returns above its WACC, is still expected to grow its NAV by retained profits and is still expected to make an aggregated PBT of £95m in the next three financial years. This also represents a valuation mis-alignment in our view.

Our fair value is set, pragmatically at this stage, more by reference to current NAV than to our normal route of EPS and PE ratio but even on this cautious basis, the shares still appear under-valued. We retain our fair value estimate at 355p and even on this more cautious basis, the shares look under-valued by over 60p or more than 20%.

BE11:55am

Telford, for those unfamiliar, does build to rent.
